items.title: Trait emotion regulation predicts momentary self-esteem level and variability in adolescents’ daily lives
items.author: Jenny Wagner
items.content: Analyzing experience sampling data from 408 adolescents, this study shows that the emotion regulation strategies reappraisal, reflection, social sharing, and expressive suppression are differentially related to momentary self-esteem level and variability.

items.title: Neural evidence for the effects of behavioral memory updating following fear conditioning
items.author: Laura E. Simons
items.content: This study examined whether behavioral memory updating can reduce fear in adolescents with and without chronic pain. While self-reported fear did not differ, neural data revealed distinct vmPFC-amygdala connectivity supporting memory updating.

items.title: How disconfirmatory evidence shapes confidence in decision-making
items.author: Kobe Desender
items.content: Re-analyzing nine datasets and a new experiment, we show that confidence relies on evidence conflicting with one’s choice. This “response-incongruentevidence” effect reflects heightened sensitivity near decision boundaries during judgement.

items.title: Personal agency and social connection are associated with loneliness over time
items.author: Todd Chan
items.content: Longitudinal study shows loneliness is associated with distinct patterns of social connection and personal agency. Four prototypes identified across waves predict loneliness levels, with transitions among them associated with loneliness changes.

items.title: Revealing Key Dimensions Underlying the Recognition of Dynamic Human Actions
items.author: Angelika Lingnau
items.content: Large-scale similarity ratings of 768 short action videos uncover 28 interpretable dimensions—such as interaction, sport, and craft—offering a framework to quantify and compare human actions.

items.title: Hope as an enabler of climate change adaptation
items.author: Katharine H. Greenaway
items.content: Hope has the capacity to be a powerful driving force for adaptation. Hope can, in theory, spur adaptation to climate change in situations where individuals and collectives identify adaptation goals and pathways; likewise, effective collective adaptation can reinforce hope.

items.title: Sequence-to-sequence models with attention mechanistically map to the architecture of human memory search
items.author: Qiong Zhang
items.content: This study shows that foundational architectures in machine learning, sequence-to-sequence models with attention, mirror mechanisms of human memory. They can serve as alternative memory models, capturing behavior and aiding performance understanding.

items.title: Everyday norms have become more permissive over time and vary across cultures
items.author: Paul A. M. Van Lange
items.content: A survey across 90 societies reveals that variation and change in everyday norms are explained by a single value dimension: the priority societies place on individualizing versus binding moral concerns.
